ANNUAL REPORT

OF THE

DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS

OF THE

NORTH-WEST TERRITORIES

For Eight Months Ending
August 31

AND OF THE

PROVINCE OF ALBERTA

For Four Months Ending
December 31

1905

PRINTED BY ORDER OF THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY

Edmonton:
James E. Richards, Government Printer
1907
To His Honour

Amedee Emmanuel Forget,
Lieutenant Governor of the North-West Territories of Canada.

Sir,—
I have the honour to transmit herewith the Annual Report of the Department of Public Works from January 1st to August 31st, 1905.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

G. H. V. Bulyea,
Commissioner of Public Works.

PROVINCIAL REPORT

| Branch                          | Page |
|---------------------------------|------|
| Correspondence Branch           | 108  |
| The Steam Boilers Ordinance     | 108  |
| Accountant's Branch             | 112  |
| Surveys Branch                  | 113  |
| Engineering Branch              | 119  |
| Local Improvement Branch        | 123  |
G. H. V. BULYEA, Esq., M. L. A.,
Commissioner of Public Works.

SIR,—I have the honour to submit the report of the Department of Public Works of the North-West Territories for the first eight months of the year 1905.

The increase and extension of the work in the department, referred to in the last Annual Report, has continued, as will be found from the detailed information in the following pages. This increase was to be expected from the large influx of settlement and extension of the areas within which the department has been called upon to perform public works during the season.

It is gratifying to be in a position to report no loss of structures, or serious damage by flood, as was the case in 1904, and while this is partially accounted for by the absence of excessive floods, the more permanent class of structures put in since 1901, many of which have been severely tested, are in a very considerable measure responsible for the absence of loss, and while in many cases the expenditures have been heavy, I think the results so far warrant the departure from more primitive methods, which in so many cases failed to withstand the floods and freshets when tested. The system of putting in steel superstructures as far as possible has been followed as in 1904, and a very considerable number of permanent bridges now stand as a valuable asset in the Territories.

A large amount of road improvements was carried on as in 1904, in large and small local improvement districts and the same policy of concentrating the improvements on leading trails as far as possible was also adhered to, it being evident that expenditures on such works outside of what the local improvement districts are able to perform, should as far as possible be made upon the leading trails or roads, with a view to benefiting the largest number of settlers for the expenditure. The amount of road work undertaken previous to September 1st was not large, as it had been found advisable to generally undertake extensive improvements after this date when the country was dryer and work could be performed in a better manner and at less cost than earlier in the season.

Though contracts were let and some fireguarding was undertaken previous to September 1st, a considerable portion of it was finished after that date.

A comparatively dry season again demonstrated the shortage of water in several localities, and that the few machines operated by the department are not of sufficient capacity to cope with the requirements, and it is gratifying to note that the settlers are beginning to realize the importance of helping themselves to procure water supply in such localities.

The areas organized under The Local Improvement Ordinance up to August 31st, 1905, is very gratifying and generally speaking the councils are showing a marked interest in looking after their own local affairs, which is resulting in a lot of good work being done, besides placing the department in a position to deal with the council as a body representing the district in preference to the confusion that generally arises when aiming to deal
with public improvements on private requests and recommendations, and while individual councillors seem to feel called upon to make requests and carry on communications about the needs of the particular divisions of their district they are generally beginning to realize the fact that such recommendations and communications should emanate from their local improvement council as a body through their secretary, otherwise their secretary is not kept in touch with the business he is paid to conduct and confusion frequently arises that should be avoided; but in this respect it is a matter of gratification to note an improvement and general marked interest in their local affairs.

Owing to the very low water in most of the large streams where ferries are operated considerable difficulty was experienced in connection with their operation.

Only two steam dredges were operated this season, one upon drain No. 110 south of Strathcona, which was nearly completed at the end of August, and the other upon drain No. 30 between Morningside and Lacombe, it having been decided that no additional drainage schemes would be undertaken until the question of assessing the lands benefited could be more satisfactorily dealt with.

The total expenditure incurred by the department for the first eight months of the year and paid out of general revenue amounts to $276,442.57. This cannot conveniently be compared with the expenditures for the first eight months of 1904 as the accounts for that year were closed at the end of the year instead of at the end of August as in 1905.

The expenditures are therefore appended for the information of the public.

Your obedient servant,

JOHN STOCKS,
Deputy Commissioner.

The above statement shows that a large amount of work has been handled by this branch during the portion of the year covered by this report. The daily average number of communications, although larger than in years previous to 1904, does not reach the number for that year and this is due to the fact that for a month or two previous to August 31st the staff were kept busy separating records and various matters which in the usual course of events would have been dealt with by the government but were held back for reference to the Provincial Governments.

**The Coal Mines Regulations Ordinance, 1905.**

Inside staff .................................. 1 clerk and stenographer.
Outside staff .................................. 1 inspector.

The large increase in the number of new mines opened in the Provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan during the past year is a strong indication of the rapid advance the provinces are making both with regard to population and the operation of industrial enterprises. A tabulated list is given below:

**Output of coal during the year 1905.**

| Anthracite coal       | 43,653 "       |

| Year | Tons     |
|------|----------|
| 1901 | 346,649  |
| 1902 | 510,674  |
| 1903 | 622,939  |
| 1904 | 782,931  |
| 1905 | 1,016,339|

It will be seen from these figures that there has been a very steady increase in output, the past year being nearly 200% more than 1901.

Edmonton, January 19th, 1906.

John Stocks, Esq.,
Deputy Commissioner of Public Works,
Regina, N.W.T.

Sir,—I have the honour here-with as inspector of coal mines for the North-West Territories in submitting my annual report for the year ending 31st of December, 1905.

The first eight months of the past year refers to the North-West Territories and the latter four months to the Provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan.

In arriving at the total output of coal for the year it was a difficult matter to have the companies send in different returns for the separate
months in the year, so it was decided to tabulate the whole output of the North-West Territories and the new Provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan in one.

The large increase in output above the previous year has been mostly in the Province of Alberta though the coal output in Saskatchewan has also increased in proportion to the increase in population, the coal in Saskatchewan being altogether used for domestic purposes and stationary boilers, while the large coal consumption in Alberta is for locomotive purposes besides stationary boilers and domestic use.

Summary of Statistics, 1905.

| Description                                                                 | Number |
|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------|
| Number of new mines opened in 1905                                          | 22     |
| Number of mines that have been in operation in the North-West Territories   |        |
| since statistics were first tabulated                                       | 115    |
| Number of mines known to be in operation at present                         | 75     |
| Number of mines abandoned in 1905                                           | 5      |
| (All the workings were concentrated in other openings)                      |        |
| Number of tons of coal produced in 1905                                     | 1,000,000 |
| Number of tons of coke produced in 1905                                     | (about) 15,000 |
| Number of persons employed inside the mines                                  | (about) 2,000 |
| Number of persons employed outside the mines                                 | (about) 800 |
| Total number of accidents inside the mines                                   | 12     |
| Total number of accidents outside the mines                                  | 3      |
| Number of non-fatal accidents inside the mines on record                    | 17     |
| Number of non-fatal accidents outside the mines on record                   | 1      |

The points at which coal is produced can well be grouped into districts. I will treat briefly of the companies operating in these districts, their plants and the development work of the mines.

Blairmore and Frank District.

The International Coal & Coke Co., Limited,
Denison Colliery, Coleman, Alta.

H. N. Galer, general manager.
E. E. Reynolds, general superintendent of mines
Geo. L. Fraser, mine superintendent and master mechanic.
J. W. Powell, mine manager.

This company's mine is situated in the eastern extremity of the coal mining industry of the district. Their openings comprise a main entry driven in the coal on No. 2 seam with a cross-cut tunnel through the measures to No. 4 seam. Another opening is by a slope on No. 2 seam forming one lift of coal and No. 4 will also be tapped from the foot of this slope. The system of working is pillar and stall. The improvement at this colliery during the past year has been the completion of the slope on No. 2 seam and the installation of a hoisting plant to operate it. An additional battery of boilers and two new air locomotives for the mine. A duplicate electric plant is nearly completed to run the ventilating fan and lighting. The Ottumwa box car loader has proved a great success handling over 1,000 tons in eight hours.
The Canadian American Coal & Coke Company, Limited,
Frank, Alberta.

F. A. Hill, general manager.
Lawrence Harris, mine superintendent.
John Robertson, mine manager.
Alex McGregor, pit boss.

The improvements at this mine are the installation of a new fan and a battery of boilers. The trail rope haulage in the mine has greatly reduced the cost in that department. The system of working the mine has had to be altered several times and I think improvements have been made especially to the advantage of the safety of the miner although there will always be elements of danger in this mine to be met with that cannot be eliminated so easily as in a flat seam or one with a less degree of pitch. An unfortunate incident happened in the workings on the 19th April last whereby the inside workings went on fire, the cause of which is still unaccounted for. I was wired for and immediately proceeded to the mine. After consulting with the management and an examination of the plans as to the point at which the fire had been closed off by stoppings, I decided to call in another inspector and mine managers in consultation. At my invitation Messrs. Drinnan and Colville, mine managers of the Crow's Nest Pass Coal Co., Mr. Whiteside, general manager of the West Canadian Collieries, and Inspector Morgan, of British Columbia, met me at Frank the following morning. With the mine officials and representatives of the miners' union the foregoing gentlemen and myself entered the mine and examined the stoppings and general condition of the mine carefully. After a conference it was decided that it was quite safe for the mine to be opened outside the stoppings. After the inside workings being closed for over a month, the stoppings were opened and the seat of fire examined but found to be still burning with little chance of putting it out. That portion was again closed up and a request made by me to the management that the mine should not be opened until the new fan was in condition to thoroughly handle the problem of ventilation and new openings made to the surface so that the air could be divided into splits. This idea was carried out and the inside area again opened up last month when it was found that the fire had been entirely damped out. The only evidence left of the fire was charred wood and some of the coal coked. The mine is now assuming a normal condition.

The Western Canadian Collieries, Limited,
Blairmore, Alta.

O. E. S. Whiteside, general manager.
W. P. Williams, general mine superintendent.
W. W. Leach, mining engineer.
Raoul Green, mine manager, Lille Colliery.
Relief fire boss.
Chas. Emerson, mine manager, Bellvue Colliery.
John Anderson, fire boss.

The Lille colliery of this company, six miles north of Frank, is producing about six hundred tons per day. All the screenings from this plant
are made into coke. The coal after being dumped over an automatic tipple passes on to shaking screens and picking tables. The screened coal is used for locomotive purposes and the screenings taken to a Luhrig washer. Here the coal is washed from containing an ash of seventeen to eighteen per cent. to a coal containing only about eight per cent ash. The capacity of the washer is 400 tons per day.

Bellevue colliery operated by the same company is a fairly large producer. The north gangways have been in faulty ground for some time but recently the coal has opened out to its regular size. A new tipple has been built during the past year and a battery of boilers and a four drill compressor added to the plant.

**The Hillcrest Coal Co.,**
Frank, Alta.

C. P. Hill, general manager.
Chas. Chestnut, pit boss.

This company has just lately started operations and are certainly making preparations for a large output; a railway and tramway has just been completed to the mine. The development of the mine is proceeding rapidly on two seams.

**The Breckenridge Lund Coal Co.,**
Lundbrek, Cowley.

Wm. Addie, mine manager.

Work progressed very slowly at this mine during the past year on account of the installation of new machinery. They were held back for over three months on account of its non-arrival but are now pushing ahead with great vigor in the erection of a steel pit-head frame and placing of the machinery. A full description of their new erections will be given in next year's report.

*Lethbridge District.*

**Alberta Railway and Irrigation Co., Limited,**
Pincher Creek Mine, Lethbridge.

P. L. Naismith, general manager.
W. D. L. Hardie, mine manager.

This company have been prospecting to the south of Pincher Creek lately and have now satisfied themselves of the value of the coal lands. The prospects are that a railway will soon be built to the property and a new coal district opened up.

**Alberta Railway and Irrigation Company, Limited,**
Lethbridge, Alberta.

P. L. Naismith, general manager.
W. D. L. Hardie, mine manager.
R. Livingstone, pit boss.
A general description of the plant and mine workings of this colliery has been given in previous annual reports. This company with their management are alive to all the new improvements for a modern colliery and as far as possible in the present location of the mine keep well up to date.

**The Bulwell Coal & Iron Company, Limited,**  
Lethbridge, Alta.  
Thomas Underwood, managing director.  
C. Padley, general manager.

This company have acquired a large area of coal land about seven miles north-east of Lethbridge and when railway connection is obtained they will be a strong competitor in the market for this class of coal.

**Taber Coal Mining Co., Limited,**  
Taber, Alta.  
Wm. Hamilton, general manager.  
Archibald Waute, mine manager.

The operations of this company are steadily increasing. During the past few months they have erected a fan and placed in position a ten drill compressor. The Taber district is a new mining camp thirty miles east of Lethbridge. The companies operating there are McPhee Bros., J. Marsh as mine manager; The Consolidated Coal Company, operated by Messrs. Marcheshault & Wilcox; The Reliance Coal Company, with W. Aubin, general manager, and Luke Raisbeck, mine manager.

*Canmore District.*

**The H. W. McNeill Co., Limited,**  
Canmore, Alta.  
W F. Little, general manager.  
J. L. Morris, mine manager.  
Wm Musgrove, pit boss.

A great many improvements have been made at this colliery, especially with regard to the safety of the mine, which is a gaseous one. The new fan erected produces eighty thousand cubic feet of air per minute. New openings have been made to the surface, allowing the air to be split often-er and more exits for the miners. Outside the mine the plant has been increased by the installation of a Jeffrey-Robinson coal washer, capable of handling four hundred tons per day. The washer is doing excellent work in having the coal placed on the market in a much cleaner condition than formerly.
The original coal breaker that this company put in has now been entirely abandoned and the whole output of the mine amounting to one thousand tons per day passes through the new breaker which has been erected on the flat close to the new opening of the mine. Three large air locomotives are now in use handling the coal from the mine. Air hoists are used inside the mine lowering the coal from the different level to the lowest one. A, B, C and D levels are now opened on No. 2 seam. During the year four other seams to the west of No. 2 have been opened out and are producing an excellent quality of Anthracite coal. The electric plant operated at the mine supplies the towns of Bankhead and Banff with light. The former town is well supplied with a water and sewerage system. In fact the whole surroundings make it one of the model mining camps of the continent, both with regard to the plant installed and the comfort of the community.

Souris District.

The Souris Coal Mining Co., Limited,
Coalfields, Sask.

Geo. Taylor, general manager.
C. C. Symons, mine manager.

The concentration of all the mines of this company at one point will tend to the development and economic working of the property, Roche Percee Mine, Souris, No. 1 and No. 2 all being operated from Taylorton No. 1 slope. A new tipple has been built with automatic arrangements for handling loaded and empty mine cars. The coal after being dumped passes over straight screen bars and is loaded in railway cars by an Ottumwa box car loader, which is doing very satisfactory work. A first class hoisting engine and battery of boilers has also been added to this plant.

Eureka Brick & Coal Co.,
Estevan, Sask.

C. Peterson, general manager.
J. Bardsley, mine manager.

The development work at this mine has been carried on systematically until now it is one of the largest shipping mines. The improvements at their brick plant have been considerable, and the machine brick they are turning out are considered the best in the market.

The other mines working in the district are increasing their output and the industry promises to be a very remunerative one.
Other coal mining districts are Medicine Hat, Knee Hill, High River and Edmonton. The latter district is developing very rapidly, especially since the advent of the Canadian Northern Railway into the city of Edmonton. The coal, although only suitable for stationary boilers and domestic use, is bound to create a large market to the east, north, west and from some distance to the south until it meets competition from the products of the other fields.

ACCIDENTS.

Of the number of accidents reported for 1905 to this department, it is sad to relate that over 50 per cent. are fatal. This no doubt is accounted for by the different companies not reporting all the slight accidents that happen in a mine. This matter of reporting all accidents I have repeatedly taken up with the management of the various collieries and have shown them that what they consider a slight accident might eventually prove fatal. All the fatal accidents I have carefully investigated and strange to say it seems they all happened through the foolhardiness of the men over anxious at their work. Fatal accidents were caused by mine cars, 2; premature explosion of dynamite, 4; suffocated by coal in chutes, 4; installing machinery in the mine, 1; fall of rock from the roof, 1. Total accidents outside the mine were caused by mine cars, 1; attending to oiling of machinery, 2.

There is one point I feel gratified to report in connection with the establishment of a mine hospital at all the large collieries, which will help to relieve the sufferings of the injured. This has been taken up especially by the employees, and in connection with it I would like to assist them; the matter to be taken up by the Legislature and made compulsory that all mining companies employing more than twenty men should have an ambulance room with stretchers and all appliances for first aid to the injured, the mine physician taking up a class of this description in which all mine managers, pit bosses and fire bosses are required to pass an examination.

WORK OF INSPECTION.

I have endeavoured to visit all the small mines in the Territories at least once during the year, and some of them oftener. It is often difficult to get notice of all the mines that are opened and in this connection if a notice was placed in the newspapers of the province twice a year with a copy of section 8 of The Coal Mines Regulations Ordinance it would assist in keeping track of the development of the industry. The large mines I have visited several times, inspecting separate sections on each visit, and any suggestions made have been carried out by the companies. I have impressed on all coal operators the necessity of keeping the mine plans up to date for inspection, and also at the small mines the great advantage of having a plan of the mine so that they can direct their operations to the advantage of their property. During the year I have only had two grievances placed before me by the miners, and in each case there was cause for complaint, not so much as to their safety, but in facility for going and coming from their work. I went over the ground with them and the defects were speedily remedied by the management. These complaints, if sent to me in writing, I would attend to as soon as possible, as there may be points that come up requiring a remedy between the dates of inspection.

EXAMINATIONS.

The regular examinations were held in April and November of 1905, only one special one being held for a fire boss certificate, the candidate having met with an accident the day before one of the regular examinations was to be held. He passed successfully. In April the examinations were held at Coleman, Bankhead and Coalfields, in all seven presenting themselves for mine managers, two failing to obtain the certificate. Six pit bosses, all passed. Seven fire bosses, all passed.

In November the examinations were at Canmore and Frank for the Province of Alberta, and at Coalfields for the Province of Saskatchewan. At the former place one presented himself for mine manager's certificate, but did not complete the examination, three for pit boss, and six for fire boss, all passing a very successful examination. At Coalfields there was granted one mine manager's certificate, and one pit boss certificate. Certificates that have been granted under sections 17 and 20 of The Coal Mines Regulations Ordinance are enumerated in tabulated form. It is gratifying to find so many men anxious to obtain certificates of competency so that they are able to fill an official position. This gaining of a certificate in a great many cases seems to be the limit to which they go, as I find the
operators have great difficulty in securing suitable men to occupy the official positions open. The reason for this seems to be that wages are more and easier made at the coal face. Also with regard to men being suitable for a position; unless he follows up this class of work he cannot expect to develop the executive ability that is necessary in an official. The wages made by the miners digging on contract vary from $75 to $180 per month, according to the place assigned him or his ability to mine coal. General wages for day labourers are as follows:

PROSPECTS.

The coal industry of the new provinces is seemingly an unlimited quantity from the number of coal mines that were opened last year and the year previous. This I think is rather an optimistic view to take but there is no doubt the influx of immigration and the starting of manufactures will keep most of them busy during the winter months at least. The enormous increase in railway building and naturally the increased consumption of coal is a great factor in the coal mining industry. The coal of Northern Alberta is not a suitable locomotive coal, but the time may come when a process of using the slack in the shape of briquettes will solve the problem. The development of the oil wells and stone quarries in the south, cement works and mineral prospects in the west, and the gas wells of the north, are a strong indication of the wealth and prosperity of the country. All these natural resources just mentioned should I think be included in the future legislation for the protection of life and property.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,
Frank B. Smith,
Inspector of Coal Mines.

The foregoing report addressed to Mr. Stocks, late Deputy Commissioner of Public Works for the North-West Territories, contains all the information with regard to the coal mines of Saskatchewan. Since the formation of the province four months ago the only fact to be recorded is the increased growth of the coal mining industry, seven new mines having started operations since then. The following is a report of the work in connection with the administration of The Steam Boilers Ordinance for the eight months commencing January 1st and ending August 31st, 1905.

The appointment of an additional inspector, referred to in last year's report, has been made, Mr. Burrows M. Smyth of Moose Jaw being appointed to the position on May 5th.

The names and addresses of the inspectors are as follows:

Wm. Waller
Jos. Buxton
Wm. Mayhew
David Fraser
Burrows M. Smyth

Whitewood.
Calgary.
Whitewood.
Strathecona.
Moose Jaw.

Inspection of Boilers.

The work of inspecting the steam boilers in the Territories during the past eight months has been accomplished under considerable disadvantage to the inspectors. Three of the five officials were obliged to cover ground that was practically new to them, and on this account difficulty was experienced in locating the boilers. An open spring, however, permitted them to commence their duties in good time, and I am pleased to report that the inspection work is progressing satisfactorily.

A large number of new threshing outfits have come into the Territories, and much time has been spent by the inspectors looking these up for the purpose of inspecting the boilers.
The total number of boilers inspected to date is nine hundred and three as against seven hundred and sixty during the same period last year. The inspectors have reported the majority of these boilers in good condition.

They might be summed up as follows:

| Condition   | Number |
|-------------|--------|
| Good        | 760    |
| Very fair   | 70     |
| Fair        | 52     |
| Poor        | 19     |
| Condemned   | 2      |

There are two casualties to report under section 22 of the Ordinance, which occurred in Inspector Fraser's district. A report of these casualties will be found in the annual report of the said inspector, appended hereto.

Examination of Engineers.

It was found necessary to discontinue, to a large extent, the old system of holding engineers' examinations for final certificates during the summer months. The number of boilers was increasing so rapidly that it was thought advisable to have the inspectors devote the greater part of their time, while the mild weather lasted, to inspection work. Accordingly most of the examinations were held in the winter months. Some doubt was entertained as to whether or not it would be possible to get the engineers to attend examinations held at this time of the year, owing to the fact that many of them would have returned to their homesteads and some would be engaged upon other work in out of the way places, thus changing their post office addresses and making it difficult to reach them through the mails. But as the returns for the ensuing eight months show, most gratifying results have been obtained. By referring to the schedule attached to this section of the report, it will be observed that three hundred and thirty-five engineers were examined, which is seventy-four in excess of the total number examined during the entire year 1904.

The interest exhibited by the engineers throughout the Territories in regard to the examinations is steadily increasing, and as a consequence there has been a marked improvement in the number of final certificates issued. As in previous years, all engineers' certificates have been issued at the department, upon the recommendations of the inspectors.

Under section 29 of the Ordinance the inspectors have orally examined about one hundred engineers for provisional certificates.

The portion of subsection 1 of section 29 authorizing the issue of provisional certificates to persons furnishing proof of two years' experience as engineers has not proven so satisfactory as expected.

The following schedule has been drawn up to illustrate the work performed in connection with The Steam Boilers Ordinance. As might be expected it has been necessary to conduct a considerable volume of correspondence to accomplish this work:

I held a series of examinations at thirteen different points. Following that work I inspected the stationary boilers at Regina and Moose Jaw.

On March 10th I received orders to proceed to Battleford to superintend the repairing and launching of the steam ferry at that point, which work was done successfully. Repairs were ordered on thirty-seven boilers or their steam connections; new safety valve on one, and new steam gauges on five.

There are quite a number of the steam gauges of an inferior quality, and it is almost impossible to set them true with the test gauge as they vary from five to ten pound.

Forty-one boilers came into my district, twenty-one new and twenty that had been in use before; thirty-three went away, that is they were either sold or traded off for new, leaving an increase of eight boilers over last year in the part of the district I have covered.

I held thirty-nine advertised examinations, having covered the southeast district as well as the north, as there was no inspector for that district in the early part of the year.

During the greater part of the month of August, I was working along the Canadian Northern Railway, which took up a lot of time as the number of boilers were few and were a long way apart.

I have had no accident reported to me during the year.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

I held examinations at various places in the districts during February and March, when sixty-six candidates wrote for final certificates. I also held examinations at Strathcona on August 25th, 26th, 28th, when twenty-three candidates took advantage of the last chance of writing under the Territorial Government. I issued two permits between January 1st and August 31st. During this period there was one prosecution for illegal operation.

Two fatal accidents occurred in my district during the spring and summer. In one case Mr. Thomas Rattary, the engineer in Cushing Bros. sash and door factory, was thrown upon the main drive belt and sustained injuries from which he died in two days; in the other case Mr. Chas. Sanderson was caught by a key extending beyond the end of a shaft in his brickyard and received injuries from which he died. Guards have been placed in several dangerous places since to prevent as far as possible accidents of a similar nature in future.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

David Fraser,
Inspector of Steam Boilers.
Sir,—I have the honour to submit my annual report as an inspector of steam boilers for the year ending August 31st, 1905, in accordance with The Steam Boilers Ordinance.

I commenced my duties on May 5th, and was assigned south-eastern Assiniboia as my field of work. I inspected one hundred and seventy-five boilers; of that number twenty-seven were new and twelve came into the district. The number of different classes and the conditions are as follows:

| Class                  | Number |
|------------------------|--------|
| Locomotive traction    | 94     |
| Locomotive table       | 38     |
| Return tubular section | 15     |
| Return tubular portable| 18     |
| Return tubular stationary | 8   |
| Vertical stationary    | 1      |
| Mining locomotive      | 1      |

CONDITION OF BOILERS.

| Condition | Number |
|-----------|--------|
| Good      | 143    |
| Very fair | 21     |
| Fair      | 10     |
| Poor      | 1      |

There have been no accidents or casualties reported to me during the year.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

B. M. Smyth,
Inspector of Steam Boilers.

REGINA, August 31st, 1905.

JOHN STOCKS, Esq.,
Deputy Commissioner of Public Works,
Regina, N.W.T.

Sir,—I have the honour to report as follows regarding the work in the surveys branch during the past year.

Early in the year it was expected that the new Provinces of Saskatchewan and Alberta would be erected about July 1st. The records of the department would then be divided and turned over to the new
provinces, that the surveys made would be of value to them and the lands required as right-of-way for public improvements form a valuable asset. An effort was therefore made to have all field work fully reported on and action, so far as was possible, taken to close outstanding matters regarding the acquirement of titles and payment of compensation to the owners of the land affected.

Heretofore we have been filing our plans in accordance with The North-West Territories Act, the action making them in reality vesting plans, from which the registrar of land titles was empowered to issue title, in fee simple, in the name of the Crown for lands covered thereby. Owing to the alleged confliction between the provisions of The North-West Territories Act, referred to, and The Land Titles Act, F. F. Forbes, registrar of land titles at Regina, deemed it advisable to secure a ruling from the bench and the matter was therefore placed before Mr. Justice Newlands, who ruled that in his opinion The North-West Territories Act only provided for an easement in respect to the area required for roads as shown on the plans.

In the face of this ruling the registrar refused to issue any more titles in fee simple, in the name of the Crown, therefore, the plans which had been sent to the land titles office and in respect to which no action regarding registration had been taken, were withdrawn and held in the vault of the department pending an anticipated amendment to the Act in order that easement might not be created where we were obliged to pay compensation, and considered that a clear title was the only satisfactory guarantee for moneys expended.

The matter was then submitted to Ottawa but the Minister of the Interior deemed it inadvisable to make amendments to The Land Titles Act owing to the fact that the land titles offices would in the near future be handed over to the new Provinces, and each would then have power to provide its own laws regarding this matter. On this account we still have no titles for a great deal of the land on which public moneys have been expended. In urgent cases and where difficulties were liable to arise, we secured title by transfer, but owing to the increased work in the branch in having copies of the records prepared to be handed over to the new provinces we were able to deal with only a comparatively small number of cases, and the responsibility of settling these long standing matters is left to the respective Governments.

Strict attention was paid, however, to the matter of reservation for roadway through lands for which patents had not already issued from the Crown and the assistants of the several district engineers were employed in making tracings of the plans of the surveys for roads, where such a reservation was possible, and certified copies of the plans were placed on file in the Department of the Interior, as the Federal Government had kindly consented to recognize such plans.

The work carried on by the branch may be summarized as follows:

|--------------------------------------------------|--------|

| Surveys for which instructions were issued        | 129    |

In addition to the regular clerical work of the branch it was found necessary to have a number of the books copied that the department of the new provinces might have a complete record of all matter regarding surveys affecting the area which they would be called upon to deal. One temporary clerk was employed to assist the regular staff; in this way the work of division did not impede the regular correspondence connected with the branch and when the time for dividing the records arrived there was no unnecessary delay.

With a view to closing out all unfinished work the regular specific instructions were not sent to the district surveyors and engineers to any great extent, each being given a list of all surveys which had been asked for within his district, and all were advised to make a special effort to close up any surveys which had been started, and when passing over their district, to attend to "requested" surveys that appeared to be urgent.

When it transpired that the division of the Territories into provinces would not take place until September 1st the surveyors were asked to continue as before in hopes that they, being in close touch with the needs of the district, would be cognizant of what should require immediate attention.

At the closing of the work in connection with this branch of the department it might not be amiss to mention the fact that the business of the department has increased very rapidly of recent years, and the system inaugurated many years ago regarding district surveyors, and engineers will be hardly sufficient to cope with the work required by the new provinces. The work in the outlying districts was necessarily light, and as it was considered advisable to retain the services of a competent engineer, who could be referred to on matters of importance, and the duties at that time were insufficient to warrant the payment of a salary equal to that which might be earned elsewhere by a competent man, they were given the privilege of doing private work which would not interfere with departmental duties, in order to allow them to augment their departmental salaries. The time has now come, I think, when the departments of the new Governments will require the services of the best men that can be procured, and the difference in salary necessary to obtain competent officials should not be a consideration compared with the additional values received from undivided and efficient services rendered.
In May, T. H. Wiggins, D.L.S., who had been in charge of the public works district of Centre Assiniboia in connection with his duties as drainage engineer for the Territories, tendered his resignation to open a private surveying and engineering business in the city, and the services of J. A. Carbert, D.L.S., were secured to continue the work of the district. The reports received from the district surveyors and engineers are subtended and will show the works undertaken in each district.

Your obedient servant,
F. J ROBINSON,
Director of Surveys.

Sir,—I beg to submit the following report with regard to the work done by me in the public works district of Lacombe for that portion of the season of 1905 ending August 31st.

In the early part of the season, that is the winter months, I was employed, with my assistant in completing and checking the returns of surveys made in the previous year.

Owing to the instructions from the department, I did not organize a party for field work until after July 1st; in the meantime, however, all the minor surveys and inspections which could be reached from here were completed, saving a considerable amount of unnecessary travel by my party when organized.

On July 7th I left Red Deer, working north and completing all surveys west and in the vicinity of the Calgary and Edmonton branch of the Canadian Pacific Railway, reaching Wetaskiwin about the end of the same month.

From Wetaskiwin I proceeded with my party to Duhamel P.O., thence north and west to Township 48 Range 23 west Fourth Meridian and back to Wetaskiwin.

On completing several surveys west of, and in the vicinity of Wetaskiwin, I proceeded east along the Wetaskiwin branch of the C.P.R. as far as Quarrel Lake. From this point I worked southwesterly, being engaged in the survey of the road near Ferry Point P.O. at the date of the inauguration of the province.

In addition to the surveys and drainage work completed, I made a number of special inspections, the party in the meantime being in charge of my assistant.

Below will be found a schedule of new roads, road diversions, drains and reports, including cross sections for bridges, which were completed by myself and party up to August 31st.

Your obedient servant,

A. E. Farncomb,

CALGARY, January 1st, 1906.

JOHN STOCKS, Esq.,
Deputy Commissioner, Department of Public Works,
Regina, Sask.

SIR,—I have the honour to submit the following report of the work performed by me in the public works district of Calgary from the 1st of January to the 31st of August, 1905.

In compliance with your instructions no regular party was organized before the 19th of July; up to that date I travelled alone or with one man, hiring labourers and teams when required. From the beginning of the year to that date I visited the following places: Millarville (twice), Priddis, Okotoks (twice), High River, Nanton, Didsbury, Olds, Nose Creek bush trail (twice), Edmonton trail, 13 miles up (twice), and Macleod trail, 6 miles up. Between these travels I was in the office preparing, with the help of my assistant, the plans and returns of the surveys made.

On the 19th of July, having organized a party of three labourers and a cook, I took my camp up north, to survey some diversions of the Edmonton trail in Township 25-1w5. From there I moved to the west side of Nose Creek, to complete the diversions on the Nose Creek bush trail.

This survey was much longer than I expected and kept me at work until the 16th of August, thirty-four days, counting the eight days' work done in June. This trail had been surveyed with a view of shortening distances, regardless of rough and low ground, with the
result that traffic could not follow the survey and went far from it in many places; I had to re-locate the old trail and survey diversions where needed. As the west end of this trail and part of the east branch go over rough ground, partly covered with scrub and brush, the work was slow with three men only to open two lines most of the distance.

For the latter part of August, I moved my camp south of Calgary and surveyed diversions in the vicinity of Okotoks, Millarville and High River, reaching Cayley on the 31st of the month. During that part of the year I was eighty-seven days absent from the office for field work; deducting from these Sundays, stormy days and days of travel, leaves fifty-four days of actual work in the field.

**Schedule of surveys made for this part of the season.**

**OLD TRAILS.**

- Resurvey and diversions of Nose Creek bush trail, from section 9, township 25-1w5 to section 18, township 28-4w5, and east branch from section 10, township 28-4w5, to section 30, township 28-3w5.
- Diversion of the Calgary and Edmonton trail in township 25-1w5.

- In sections 29 and 30-20-29w4 and sections 13-20-30w4, west of Okotoks.
- In sections 7, 8 and 9, township 19-27w4. Completed from last year's survey.

**ROAD DIVERSIONS.**

**EXAMINATIONS.**

About seven days were lost during the first part of the season on account of snow and rain, but from the 15th of June to the end of the season, dry weather prevailed.

There was not as much time lost travelling through the district as in previous years; this is due in part to the dryness of the season, but
to the large amount of improvements made on the main roads is also due a good share of the shortening of travels.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Albert Chas. Talbot,
District Surveyor and Engineer.

MACLEOD, 10th January, 1906.

John Stocks, Esq.,
Deputy Commissioner of Public Works for the North-West Territories,
Regina.

Sir,—I have the honour to submit my annual report, showing the work done in the Macleod public works district between the 1st of January and the 31st August during the year 1905.

Between the 1st January and 1st April I was generally occupied at headquarters, Macleod, in preparing returns of surveys made during the season of 1904, but several special trips were made to outside points during these months to make surveys or inspections.

In accordance with instructions received from the department, no regular party was organized until the 1st July, the date arranged for the division of the Territories into two provinces, this date being afterwards postponed until the 1st September. No full party was actually organized until that date, and the assistance of only such men as could be picked up from time to time was depended on.

The season as a whole, was favourable for surveying operations, but the difficulty of obtaining camping grounds is increasing from year to year as fences go up, and much delay occurs through this difficulty.

Separate reports accompanied by sketches have been submitted to your department on the completion of each survey made.

Following is a list showing the different surveys made.

EDMONTON, February 12th, 1906.

JOHN STOCKS, Esq.,
Deputy Minister of Public Works,
Regina, Sask.

The work of the district of West Assiniboia during the beginning of the season of 1905, after the completion of the survey returns of the previous season's work, was, owing to the expected erection of the new provinces to take place July 1st, confined chiefly to completing any unfinished work, and for this purpose no regular survey party was organized, as in previous seasons, and special instructions for any particular work were only received in a few cases, general instructions being received to travel light and work from the schedule of outstanding surveys; later in the season it became necessary to organize a larger party in order that work some distance from the railway could be undertaken, and on the 5th of August a field party was employed.

It having been arranged that Mr. J. A. Carbert, D.L.S., should take charge of my party during the latter part of the season, in order that I might take charge of the surveys branch of the Department of Public Works for the Province of Alberta, my party and outfit were handed over to that gentleman on the 21st of August, and the balance of that month, after closing up business matters in Medicine Hat, was spent with the Department at Regina, assisting in the separation of the departmental records for each province and the shipping of those belonging to Alberta.

Below is given a list of the examinations and surveys made during that part of the season that I was in the field.

I am, sir, your obedient servant,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,—I have the honour to submit the following report on work performed by me in the Qu'Appelle public works district up to August 31st.

From the beginning of the year to May 18th I was occupied chiefly in office work with my assistant in connection with preparation of returns of surveys made in previous years, and as a considerable amount of this work remained to be done my assistant continued in the office while I went into the field on above date with a small party as suggested by you to attend to the most urgent surveys and to obtain additional measurements where necessary in order to complete plans of some unfinished surveys.

The following schedules give the locations of the various surveys and examinations made:

New road in section 6-29-7w2, via Lawrie's bridge over Deer creek.

New road in section 27-28-6w2, via new bridge over creek.

New road via bridge over Hilgert creek in section 9-30-9w2 leading to Sheho.

New road along blind line north of sections 25, 26, 27 and 28-18-9w2.

New road in sections 13 and 14-18-9w2, connecting with surveyed Qu'Appelle Valley trail.

Diversions from surveyed valley road in sections 12 and 18-18-33 32 west 1st meridian.

Survey of area flooded in east § section 8-17-7w2 on account of dam erected across ravine in n.w. § section 8.

Examinations made

Examination for proposed road east of section 30-20-12w2.

Examination for proposed road from Cupar to Kutawa.

Reports on the above have been forwarded to the department.

In conclusion I may say that the outlying portions of my district are becoming rapidly settled in advance of railway construction and when stations are definitely located a large number of diversion surveys will be necessary, especially in the northern part, in order to provide suitable roads.

Your obedient servant,

Wm. T. Thomson,
District Surveyor and Engineer.

Sir,—I beg to submit the following report of work completed in the public works district of East Assiniboia from January 1st to August 31st in the year 1905.
During January, February and March, the completion of returns for surveys made during the season of 1904 fully occupied my time.

On the 9th of February the building, part of which I occupied as my office, was destroyed by fire, nothing being saved except my field notes, of which two copies were on hand, though notes of four surveys were lost. In April I made resurveys to obtain new notes to replace those burned and also made some inspections for bridges.

The beginning of May party was put in the field, working steadily until the 31st of August. Surveys for a large amount of drainage have been asked for and completed.

The surveys through the northern part of this district were chiefly drainage or grades through the deep ravines to the bridges. A number of surveys were completed and final returns sent in by the middle of July.

Sir,—Herewith I beg to submit this my report on surveys and other duties of my office performed from the 1st day of January to the 31st day of August, 1905, thus completing the record of work for the North-West Territories.

During the early part of this term I made plans and reports of my surveys of 1904 and attended to correspondence.

On the opening of the season I began my surveys, eighteen of which I finished before the end of August as enumerated below:

ROAD DIVERSIONS.

Diversion from road allowance north of section 14-48-25w2.
Diversion from road allowance south of section 23-48-25w2.
Diversion from road allowance east of sections 9 and 16-42-6w3.
Diversion from road allowance east of sections 29 and 30-48-25w2.
Diversion from road allowance east of section 28-42-2w3.
Diversion from road allowance east of section 4-43a-3w3.

NEW ROADS.

New road through east half of section 29-36-5w4.
New road through section 29-42-6w3 leading to Doukhobor ferry.
New road through the west part of section 16 and south part of section 21-44-20w2.
New road from Duck Lake through sections 32, 29, 30, 19 and 18, 42-2w3.
New road through river lots 6 to 23 inclusive, township 45-25w2, and diversion from road allowance of section 6-45-2w3.
Survey of right-of-way for access to Adam's ferry, section 5-47a-25w2.
That part of Duck Lake and Carlton trail on sections 11 and 15-45-4w3.
That part of Prince Albert and Isbester ferry trails on sections 11 and 12-48-24w2.
Survey of old trail known as Lacerte's trail from the Prince Albert and Montreal lake trail commencing at east side of section 32-49-27w2 west to the east side of section 10-50- w3.

DRAINS.

Survey of ditch to drain Duck Lake on Beardy's Indian reserve east of section 15-45-3w3.
Survey of a ditch to drain sloughs on sections 6, 5, 4, 3 and 10-50-26w2.

One of these surveys known as the Lacerte trail was about 11 miles in length, on ground that required much exploration to select the best route. Some eight miles more of survey was asked for but I found that the original road allowances would better serve the majority of the settlers. Therefore, I did not extend that survey farther west.

One of the surveys was for right-of-way to give access to the ferry cable at Adam's Crossing of the south branch of the river Saskatchewan, section 5 township 47a range 25 west 2nd meridian. Two surveys were for large drains.

That for the drainage of Duck Lake excavated two years ago has I think fully answered its purpose,—the waters of the lake having been lowered four feet, thus recovering roads and hay lands. It enabled me to survey a much needed road of about five miles south-west of the town of Duck Lake.

The other surveys were mostly of short diversions to avoid sloughs.
The survey of road in section 15 township 45 range 27 west 2nd meridian was prevented by not being on my regular routes and in the expectation of being able to undertake it at the end of the season.

Another survey (file 16381) was so far out from the last on my western circuit that I deferred it to a more convenient opportunity.

Interim reports and sketches of the surveys were sent in monthly as performed.

All of which is most respectfully submitted.

Cyrus Carroll, D.L.S.,
District Surveyor and Engineer.

From January 1st, 1905, until August 31st, 1905, being the date upon which the affairs of the North-West Government were wound up, one hundred and thirty-seven bridges were constructed, twenty-one reconstructed and fifty repaired, making a total of two hundred and eight bridges dealt with. The office work of this branch shows that two hundred and seventy-five bills of quantity, sixty-eight contracts and thirty-six plans were prepared and recorded. As stated in previous reports, standard bridge plans were prepared and the bridges were constructed as far as possible in accordance with these standard plans, excepting in cases where special designs were required. The amount of work done by this branch will be clearly illustrated by the list of roads, bridges, fireguards, etc. The usual schedule of bridges constructed, reconstructed and repaired is shown below.

The following bridges are worthy of special mention:

Bridge over the Bow River at Morley.

The timber bridge at this point having reached the limit of its life, it was found necessary in order to meet the traffic demands at that point to construct a steel bridge, and considered advisable, owing to the nature of the stream, to put in concrete substructures. The bridge was completed early in the season, and consists of two 125 ft. rivet connected steel spans with 16 ft. clear roadway and 80 ft. of timber approaches at the south end, making a substantial crossing not likely to require further expenditure for some time.

Bridge over Battle River, section 31-42-25w4.

The increased settlement and consequent traffic necessitated the construction of a bridge at the above point and after an examination by the district engineer it was decided to erect a 60 foot steel truss with one timber span of 20 feet at each end, upon pile and timber substructures which serves the interests of a very considerable settlement.
Bridge over Battle River, section 33-43-18w4, known as the Ferry Point Bridge.

The construction of a bridge on the Battle River at the above point became necessary owing to the influx of population. The structure consists of one riveted connected steel span of 100 feet with two 20 foot timber spans at each end, the truss being erected upon pile and timber piers, and provides a permanent crossing of great convenience to the settlers in that locality.

Bridge over Battle River between river lots 4 and 28, township 46 range 21 west 4th Meridian.

This structure consists of one 80 ft. riveted connected steel span with one 20 foot timber span at each end which serves the interests of a large and populous district.

Bridge over Pincher Creek at Village of Pincher.

The old structure at this point was broken down by a traction engine, and it was found necessary to replace it with a new standard steel structure of 100 foot span, riveted connected truss with four foot sidewalk, upon concrete substructures, providing a permanent crossing, the work to be completed after the establishment of the province.

Bridge over Willow Creek, between sections 36 and 6, townships 10 and 11, range 27, west 4th meridian.

Owing to the large influx of population in this section of the country south and west of Leavings, it was found necessary to construct a bridge over Willow creek to give an outlet to the town of Leavings. This structure consists of two 90 foot riveted connected steel spans with three 20 foot timber spans at one end and two at the other, and erected on pile substructures, thus providing a very substantial structure which is used by a large community.

THE CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OF ROADS.

Owing to the yearly increase and extension of settlement a large expenditure is necessary in this connection each season, and it is desirable as far as possible to distribute such expenditure upon the leading trails of roads with the object in view of eventually establishing permanent roads, and giving preference in this respect to highways most used by the public. Distributed as this work is, and carried on from year to year, the success depends largely upon the organization in each district to properly locate the most necessary works, and apply the expenditures where they will best serve the interests of the public. Lacking in this requisite, money and labour spent do not give
the best results, while with a perfect system every dollar spent should be of benefit and a good investment. Special effort is made by the department when requests for improvements are received to obtain the fullest and most reliable information in order that the greatest number may benefit by the improvements if undertaken, and at the same time the aim has been to continue improvements already undertaken. On the other hand the department while endeavouring to fulfil the trust reposed upon them must guard against those who in making the loudest demands for assistance do not always voice the most urgent needs of the country and in pressing their claims cannot consider any improvements except those that will bring direct gain to themselves, losing sight of the benefit that should accrue to the general public. This is particularly noticeable where the effort is made to divert travel from one place of business to another, and has necessitated our making most careful enquiries and investigations before acting upon such requests. In addition to the work done by local improvement districts, $35,716.00 was expended on road improvements by the department during 1905.

From the above list it will be noticed that twenty-seven ferries were operated by the department during the season. Owing to very low water during most of the season in both the North and South
Saskatchewan rivers, the operation of most of the ferries was maintained with considerable difficulty and at considerable expense. The formation of sand bars in several localities necessitated the removal of ferries to other localities. Among those moved were the Battleford Steam ferry, the Batoche ferry, and the ferry on the South Saskatchewan river west of Hanley. A new ferry was established at the Elbow on the South Saskatchewan river west of Davidson, and a new ferry on the Red Deer river at the mouth of Tail creek. The scows at Adams' and Carlton crossings were rebuilt and various other repairs and removals necessitated owing to low water.

The increased population in several new districts necessitated the operation of additional ferries, and the traffic generally was greatly increased on most of the ferries from the same cause.

FIREGUARDS.

Below is given a list of fireguards constructed or maintained during the season. It will be noticed that approximately one thousand miles of guard were plowed. An effort was made to bring all the guards up to the standard of sixteen feet in width, except in cases where two eight foot guards were provided some distance apart to permit of burning out the grass between. The usual trouble was experienced this season as in former years, by contractors not having their work completed early enough in the season, and in this connection the specifications will have to be more rigidly enforced, it frequently happening that the carelessness of an individual to properly complete work results in fires getting away.

Several portions of the country were visited by disastrous fires, and it will undoubtedly be necessary to provide a very considerable mileage of fireguards next season.

LOCAL IMPROVEMENT BRANCH.

During the first eight months of 1905, this portion of the Public Works Department was divided into three sections under a clerk in charge of each, who was directly responsible to the deputy commissioner for the work of his particular section. The office of cashier and clerk of assessment were in this way added to the branch. Other officials engaged in the work were: one assistant cashier, thirteen, clerks and three stenographers to each of whom were assigned duties in the different portions of the branch. The staff had increased January, 1905, to nearly four times what it had been in January, 1903, and an even larger number was necessary had the limited quarters provided the necessary room. The rapid growth of population in the Territories was shown in this branch as well as in every other department of the public service.

SMALL DISTRICTS.

The system of organization provided by the present local Improvement Ordinance has proved fairly popular, and many sections of the country took advantage of the privilege of organization; those in the organized small districts thus gaining complete control of the expenditure of the funds collected in and for the townships which
comprise the district. The average size of these small districts is four townships. Each of these townships in turn is represented on the council board by a regularly elected councillor. Where the population warrants it, a small local improvement district may be organized anywhere by petitioning the Commissioner to that effect.

Taxes for the current year and all arrears since the constitution of the district may be collected by the secretary-treasurer of the small district. At the end of each year a report is made to the department showing owners and occupants of lands and giving a general statement of all local improvements performed under the direction of the council during the year. A return of unpaid taxes is also sent in showing assessments which, for various reasons, are unpaid. When payments of arrears are made after the return is sent in, the secretary-treasurer is expected to report such payment on the same day as made, that no taxes may be shown outstanding on the district return on file in the department, which have been paid to the local official. Payment of arrears of taxes are accepted at all times by this branch. When received for small districts they are immediately sent on to the council to be expended on needed local improvements. In this way the sum of $24,880.83 was collected by this department and forwarded to secretary-treasurers. Following is a complete list of small districts which were formed in 1904 and 1905:

LARGE DISTRICTS.

All outlying areas not included in small district organizations or in the rural municipalities of Indian Head and Qu'Appelle are assessed direct by the Local Improvement branch, and all taxes in this connection are payable to the Deputy Commissioner of Public Works. The general tide of immigration to the Canadian North-West has caused so much land to be occupied that the number of townships in which there are no entries is being rapidly reduced, which fact accounts for this portion of the local improvement branch increasing to large proportions.

The quantity of work connected with the assessment of large districts may be estimated from the fact that in the first eight months of 1905 the sum of $90,469.89 was collected and handled in connection with large districts alone by this branch. The expenditure of taxes thus collected is controlled by the Commissioner of Public Works. The rate of assessment in large districts was one and one-quarter cents per acre. SCHOOL ARREARS.

Although school and local improvement taxes are in no way connected, this branch also collects arrears of school taxes to be forwarded to the district concerned. In this way the sum of $11,924.29 was received and placed in the hands of the secretary-treasurers.

The amount of mail matter received and sent assumed greater proportions than has been experienced in this branch at any other period.

Items sent out 112,504

ANNUAL REPORT

OF THE

DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS

OF THE

PROVINCE OF ALBERTA

FOR THE

FOUR MONTHS ENDING DECEMBER 31

1905
EDMONTON, March 28th, 1906.

Hon. W. H. Cushing, M. L. A.,
Minister of Public Works,
Edmonton, Alta.

Sir.—I have the honour to submit the report of the Department of Public Works of the Province of Alberta for the last four months of the year 1905.

It was considered advisable by the Executive to transfer a few capable and experienced men from each branch of the Public Works service with a view of starting the work of the department under the Provincial Government with the least possible interruption. A considerable amount of work being under way when the establishment of the provinces took place, it seemed in the interests of the public service to carry on this work without interruption that otherwise might occur.

The employment of the outside staff—surveyors and engineers, bridge and road foremen and their crews—was continued, all plant and equipment, the property of the Territories, in use in the Province of Alberta, remaining where it was, a fair valuation being made of it in each province and a division of these values adjusted by the liquidator.

All records and documents pertaining to the Province of Alberta were transferred to Edmonton, and the work of the department carried on without any very serious interruption.

While, as previously stated, a certain amount of work, principally in connection with the construction of bridges, was not completed upon the establishment of the provinces, the authorization of road improvements and certain bridge work was generally withheld by the Territorial administration, and consequently had to be dealt with by the Provincial Executive so as to permit of completing as much of the work as possible before winter. This, in addition to the organization of the inside staff to meet the new conditions, kept the department very busy right up to the end of the year, and while the expenditure in connection with roads and bridges was not so large as in the previous year, it was possible, owing to the favourable weather, to accomplish a good deal, the work being carried on upon the same lines as had prevailed for some time under the Territorial administration.

Your obedient servant,

JOHN STOCKS,
Deputy Minister.
The following statement will show the amount of work handled by this branch from September 1st to December 31st, 1905.

Staff ............................................ 1 chief clerk.
..................................................... 3 clerks.
..................................................... 1 messenger.

Communications received ....................................... 14,116
Total number of communications sent .................................. 20,222
Entries of cash received ........................................... 4,732

The Steam Boilers Ordinance.

Inside staff ................................................................ 1 clerk in charge.
Outside staff ......................................................................... 2 inspectors.

The following are the names and addresses of the Inspectors:

Joseph Buxton ........................................... Calgary.
David Fraser .............................................. Strathcona.

The schedule below shows the ground covered during the past four months, viz.: September 1st to December 31st in connection with the administration of The Steam Boilers Ordinance.

Number of boilers inspected ................................................ 190
Number of examinations of engineers held ........................................ 17
Number of second class engineers' certificates issued ......................... 9
Number of third class engineers' certificates issued ............................ 58
Number of provisional certificates of qualification issued ..................... 106
Number of permits for operation of steam boilers issued ................. 4

FEES COLLECTED.

For inspection of steam boilers .............................................. $920.00
For final certificates issued under section 28 .................................... 6.00
For examination of engineers .................................................. 204.00
For Provincial certificates ....................................................... 318.00
For permits for operation of steam boilers ....................................... 12.00

Total ............................................................... $1,460.00

In addition to the certificates issued as recorded in the above schedule, two second provisional certificates have been issued under subsection 2 of section 29.

It will be noticed that no first class certificates have been issued.

It is a pleasure to report that no accident has occurred during these four months for which the condition of boilers is accountable.

The reports of the staff of inspectors and a list of all final certificates issued are submitted herewith.

CALGARY, January 1st, 1906.

JOHN STOCKS, Esq.,
Deputy Minister of Public Works,
Edmonton, Alta.

Sir,—I have the honour to submit my annual report for the year 1905 as inspector of steam boilers in accordance with the provisions of The Steam Boilers Ordinance, section 19.
The number of boilers inspected by me during the past year, part after the division of the Territories from September 1st to December 31st, was one hundred and ten boilers and the following is a statement of the different classes and conditions of same:

| Class                        | Quantity |
|------------------------------|----------|
| Horizontal tubular           | 24       |
| Horizontal furnace           | 10       |
| Horizontal flue              | 1        |
| Water tube                   | 6        |
| Locomotive firebox           | 32       |
| Locomotive firebox, portable type | 11     |
| Return locomotive firebox    | 3        |
| Return tubular               | 7        |
| Upright tubular              | 15       |
| Upright cross sectional      | 1        |

CONDITION OF BOILERS INSPECTED.

| Condition                  | Quantity |
|----------------------------|----------|
| Good condition             | 81       |
| Very fair condition        | 27       |
| Fair condition             | 2        |

Since the division of the Territories I held examinations once as was advertised and had seven applicants for final certificates. I also held one since, making eight in all, which graded as follows:

| Class | Quantity |
|-------|----------|
| 1st class | 0       |
| 2nd class | 1       |
| 3rd class | 7       |

I have no accidents to report in connection with the operation of steam boilers in my district, also to state that in the south-west part of my district there are eight new boilers being installed and will be ready for inspection in March.

On account of the snow storm which came on during the end of November, all portable boilers and engines were not inspected in the Macleod district and north to Calgary. I am pleased to state that some of the larger firms are installing modern boilers from 75 horse-power to 150 horse-power and are doing away with the smaller plants which they have been prospecting with, and that the majority of the larger owners are in favour of more restriction being placed on applicants for provisional certificates or doing away with them altogether and having a fourth class, limited to a 25 horse-power and no more, also that it be printed on the bottom of every certificate "Please post up your certificate."

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

JOSEPH BUXTON,
Inspector of Steam Boilers.

---

STRATHCONA, ALTA., January 17th, 1906.

JOHN STOCKS, Esq.,
Deputy Minister of Public Works,
Edmonton, Alta.

Sir,—I have the honour to submit my annual report as inspector of steam boilers for the year 1905 in accordance with The Steam Boilers Ordinance, from September 1st to December 31st.
Since September 1st I have inspected eighty boilers, which may be classed as follows:

- Locomotive firebox: .52
- Return tubular: .15
- Horizontal tubular: .5
- Upright tubular: .5
- Furnace tubular: .2
- Upright cross sectional: .1

Of this number nineteen were new and four were brought into the district second hand. Various repairs were ordered on four boilers, new steam gauge on one and new safety valve on one.

**CONDITION OF BOILERS INSPECTED:**

| Condition    | Number |
|--------------|--------|
| Good         | 67     |
| Very fair    | 9      |
| Fair         | 4      |

During the threshing season I issued five permits for thirty days in order to enable owners to operate their machines, three of them could not get engineers and in two cases the qualified engineers left without notice.

Nine engineers wrote on the examination for final certificates.

One accident happened about November 24th east of Red Deer by an engine going through a bridge over a creek and severely injuring the engineer. This is a matter which the local Government should look into. The bridges that were sufficiently strong a few years ago to accommodate the small engines in use at that time are altogether too light to safely carry the engines that are coming into the district at the present time.

There are several ploughing engines in the district which weigh fifteen tons or over and the tendency at present is to purchase still heavier engines in future, so that bridges to be built from now on should have a carrying capacity of twenty or twenty-five tons.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

DAVID FRASER,
Inspector of Steam Boilers.
