EDMONTON, December 31st, 1905.

JOHN STOCKS, Esq.,
Deputy Minister, Department of Public Works,
Edmonton, Alta.

Sir,—I have the honour to submit the following report on the work in the surveys branch from September 1st to the end of the year 1905.

The district surveyors and engineers who were in the field for the Territorial Government in the districts which afterwards came within this province continued their work uninterrupted by the change, and as soon as the records arrived the inside business of the department was gone ahead with.

As the district men who were in the field had already received instructions for sufficient work to keep them occupied for the remainder of the season new instructions were not generally issued, but the work was merely continued as it was being carried on.

The work done is summarized below:

| Description                                                                 | Quantity |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------|
| Surveys requisitioned for during 1905, Sept. 1st to Dec. 31st               | 71       |
| Surveys completed and examinations made                                    | 108      |
| Plans received and recorded                                                | 32       |
| Field books received and recorded                                          | 5        |
| Preliminary agreements and right-of-way received and recorded              | 71       |
| Transfers received and recorded                                            | 1        |
| Certificates of title received and recorded                                | 52       |
| Amount paid for right-of-way                                               | $3,562.28|
| Miles of road not previously leased for which applications to lease have been received | 154      |
| Number of applications                                                    | 14       |
| Miles leased, renewed 9, new leases 9. Total                               | 9        |
| Number of payments made in settlement of claims to compensation for right-of-way on account of surveyed roads and drains | 85       |
| Number of owners written under the Ordinance                              | 24       |
| Number of owners written under the Ordinance, second time (on re-consideration) | 1        |
| Number of owners accepting second ruling                                  | 0        |
| Number of these cases unsettled                                           | 5        |
| Appeals to arbitration                                                    | 2        |

Although a strong effort was made during the last months of the existence of the North-West Territories to close up all outstanding matters of compensation, it was found that when the division into Provinces occurred there were many matters still requiring attention and the settling up of these cases has been made an aim in addition to the routine work of the department. I am pleased to be able to report that this effort has been fairly successful and the old outstanding cases are pretty well disposed of, with the exception of those in the district around Medicine Hat in the territory in ranges 1 to 10 west of the 4th meridian, which has been a part of the Assiniboia land registration district. This was owing to the registrar at Regina interpreting The North-West Territories Act differently from the other registrars and refusing to issue titles off vesting plans of roads.

The territory above mentioned will shortly become a part of the South Alberta land registration district, and it is hoped that then we will have matters of title soon cleared up and be able to deal with these old cases mentioned.
The recent rapid settlement of the country has caused a great increase in the requests for road surveys and also has caused a necessary change in the policy of the department in connection therewith. Some years ago, when settlement was scattered, the demands were for roads across country, regardless of regular road allowances, while now there are constantly arising objections to these old roads cutting up the lands and traffic is being diverted to the road allowances where possible and surveys of roads are only being made where the natural obstacles on the original road allowances are not easily overcome. The construction of new railway lines has also changed the lines of traffic in many cases and rendered unnecessary roads which were previously much needed.

From these causes there has been considerable work to be undertaken in re-transferring roads which were acquired and are now unnecessary.

The necessity having become apparent of requiring the undivided services of the district surveyors and engineers, instead of the past practice of allowing them the privilege of doing a certain amount of private work, it was decided that the present system would be discontinued at the end of this year, and sufficient salary paid to retain the full services of competent men.

No appointment was made to fill the vacancy caused in the Medicine Hat district by my removal to Edmonton.

In the Macleod district, Mr. A. W. Ponton, D.L.S., having accepted work from the Dominion Government resigned his position with this Government, dating from the end of the year.

In the North Alberta district, Mr. A. Driscoll, D.L.S., owing to pressure of private business was unable to undertake our work any longer and is severing his connection with the department at the end of the year. Arrangements are being made to attend to the work of this district direct from the head office, and the department has men in view for each of the other districts.

Owing to the large settlement east of Edmonton, following the railway construction through that part of the country, a large amount of work is arising and it will probably be necessary to form a new district cutting off part of the present North Alberta district, and it will also be necessary to place a surveyor and engineer at some suitable point to attend to this work.

The reports received from the district surveyors and engineers are given below and will show the work done in each district.

Your obedient servant,

L. C. Charlesworth,
Director of Surveys.

CALGARY, January 1st, 1906.

JOHN STOCKS, Esq.,
Deputy Minister Department of Public Works,
Edmonton, Alta.,

Sir,—I have the honour to submit the following report of the work performed by me in the public works district of Calgary from the 1st of September to the 31st of December, 1905.

On the 1st of September I was at Cayley with a party of four men, from that point a road was surveyed along the centre blind line of township 17 across ranges 28 and 27 to near Little Bow river.

From the 7th to the 18th of September, when the party came into Calgary, diversions were surveyed and examinations made in the vicinity of Nanton, Brant, Dinton and Gladys.

From the 19th of September, the party was detained for five days in Calgary, the horses quarantined and one had to be shot, being infected with glanders. The four others had to be tested and when proved to be free from infection were allowed to go. An examination was made and a diversion surveyed near Calgary while waiting for the horses.

From the 25th of September to the 13th of November work was done in the northern part of the district, beginning with a new road along the blind line west of Crossfield, thence north along the railway as far as Olds and Mayton, thence west to the Little Red Deer river near Eagle hills, thence south by way of Dog Pound, Beaverdam, Bradbourne and Cochrane.

The balance of the season was spent in the south-west part of the district where a few surveys and examinations had to be made in the vicinity of DeVinton, Lineham, Millerville and Priddis. On the 25th of November the party was back at headquarters, when I paid the men for the season and discharged them.

RED DEER, January 17th, 1906.

JOHN STOCKS, Esq.,
Deputy Minister of Public Works,
Edmonton, Alta.

Sir,—I beg to submit the following report regarding the work done by me in the public works district of Lacombe, from Sept. 1st to the end of the season of 1905.
On September 1st I was engaged with party in the survey of a road across the Battle river, near Ferry Point P.O. and on completing the same proceeded south, examining and surveying all roads which were found to be necessary, arriving at Red Deer on October 15th.

I left Red Deer at once for the south and on the completion of the work in the Innisfail district, proceeded to the territory lying between Red Deer and the Medicine river, disbanding the party on the 6th Nov.

Although the season was somewhat shorter than usual it will be seen from this and the report to the department previous to Sept. 1st, that the whole of the Lacombe district was covered by myself and party from Millet station on the north to Bowden station on the south and about twenty miles west and about fifty east of the Calgary and Edmonton Railway line.

In addition to the general work of surveying new roads, road diversions and drains, I made a number of special inspections, including visits to steam ditcher No. 3 between Lacombe and Morningside.

I find that in each year the work in that portion of the district lying to the south of the Red Deer river is decreasing, whereas the work in that portion lying to the north of this line is increasing, especially along the new branch railways running east of Lacombe and Wetaskiwin, which are rapidly opening up a new territory in the eastern part of the district, which will require a considerable amount of the work in order that the settlers will have access to the new towns which are springing up along these new lines.

Between the time of disbanding party and the end of the year, myself and assistant were engaged in preparing returns of surveys completed in the past summer and several minor surveys and inspections, which could be reached from here.

Below will be found a schedule of new roads, road diversions, drains and inspections completed between September 1st and the end of the season of 1905.

LOCAL IMPROVEMENT BRANCH.

Staff

1 clerk in charge.
1 cashier.
3 permanent clerks.
2 temporary clerks.
1 stenographer.

During the last four months of 1905 the work of this branch of the Department of Public Works pertaining to the Province of Alberta was carried on under the Government of Alberta. The Ordinances belonging to this branch were administered in practically the same manner as they had been during the first eight months of the year by the local improvement branch of the Public Works Department of the North-West Territories. Owing to the extra amount of work caused by the organization of the work in the new Province, it was found impossible to take any action towards forfeiting lands for nonpayment of taxes, and therefore this matter had to stand over.

SMALL DISTRICTS.

An attempt was made to collect the arrears of local improvement taxes which were still outstanding on the lands in small districts, from assessments made prior to the organization of said districts. Notices calling for payment of these arrears were sent out, and the sum of $8,532.20 was collected and forwarded to the treasurers of the different districts.

LARGE DISTRICTS.

In the large local improvement districts the collection of taxes was carried on as usual, tax notices having all been sent out from the Department of Public Works at Regina, the amount collected during the four months being $19,809.48. This together with the $459.29 collected for tax certificates, costs for redemption of forfeited lands, interest and other matters made a total collection in the large district account of $20,268.77. The collections from the large local improvement districts were made up as follows:

$19,809.48
The collections of arrears of school taxes was also carried on, and the sum of $1,474.53 was collected and forwarded to the treasurers of the school districts.

VILLAGES.

No villages were established nor were there any villages proclaimed towns in the Province of Alberta during the last four months of the year 1905. Some applications from areas desiring to be established were received prior to December 31st, but these applications were not received soon enough to allow of the establishment of any villages prior to the end of the year.

The amount of mail received by this branch of the department increased very rapidly towards the end of the year; there being four times as many letters received in the month of December as in the month of September.

The amount of mail matter received was nine thousand seven hundred and seventy items. The mail sent out amounted to seventeen thousand three hundred and fifty eight items, which amount was composed of two thousand seven hundred and sixty-one letters, four thousand and ninety-seven receipts, and ten thousand and thirty-five notices and four hundred and sixty-five cheques.
